subject: Re: [junit] OT: Streams / Readers/ Writers or files, what do you use and how do you test?

messageBody:
Hi Cédric, sorry about spelling your name wrong.ö

> It's not a matter of preference. Sometimes I work with streams, sometimes I
> work with File objects and sometimes, I just want the content of the file as
> an array of strings or as one big String. It's unfortunate that the latter
> is still not supported in the JDK.

The reason I am asking is that I always seem to prefer a
FileStream/Reader/Writer to working directly with a file. I have
noticed that a lot of people seem to have a preference towards working
with files rather than Streams/Readers/Writers.

If I would want random acces or something I would opt for working
directly with files but I can't recall needing that, I have not
written storages or such. Another occation when I use file objects is
when doing file system management, creating listing, renaming, working
with directories etc. But when I read/write data i always use
streams/readers/writers.

Could you give an example when you think that reading/writing directly
to/from a File is better than a stream.

Also, when you have your array of Strings or single big string, what
do you typically do with it? I can think of some things but I am
curious.

One of the reasons I prefer Streams so much is because of the
advantage of being able to direct state to memory rather than disk and
vary source/target media (like parser might just aswell get its input
from a keyboard, socket, file, memory-location, it should not be bound
to a file). The first point of directing state to memory is
indispensable when testing.

Also, files imply mutable state of the worst kind. Most of the bugs I
find in my code have to do with mutablestate in one way or another and
thus I try to avoid it when possible. That is also why I am a fan of
interactionbased testing.

Just tossing some of my reasoning in there to be analysed, questioned
and developed.
/J
